revision.comment: /* Composition */ fix verse template formatting
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=October 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} [[Image:Te Raparaha, chief of the Kawias, watercolour by R. Hall, c. 1840s.jpg|thumb|right|240px|[[Te Rauparaha]], Ngāti Toa chief, 1840s]] "'''Ka Mate'''" is a [[Māori people|Māori]] [[haka]] composed by [[Te Rauparaha]], war leader of the [[Ngāti Toa]] tribe of the [[North Island]] of [[New Zealand]].
==Composition== Te Rauparaha composed "Ka Mate" circa 1820 as a celebration of life over death after his lucky escape from pursuing [[Ngāti Maniapoto]] and [[Tainui|Waikato]] enemies.<ref name="Pomare">{{cite web| last = Pōmare | first = Mīria | url = http://www.teara.govt.nz/NewZealanders/MaoriNewZealanders/NgatiToarangatira/4/ENZ-Resources/Standard/2/en | title = Ngāti Toarangatira – Chant composed by Te Rauparaha | work = Te Ara – the Encyclopedia of New Zealand | publisher = Ministry for Culture & Heritage | date = 12 February 2014 | accessdate = 31 August 2015}}</ref><ref name=Guidelines>{{cite web | url = http://www.ngatitoa.iwi.nz/wp-content/uploads/PhotoGallery/2010/09/Haka-Ka-Mate-Guidelines_Final2.pdf | format = pdf | title = Haka Ka Mate Attribution Act 2014 Guidelines | publisher = Ministry of Business, Innovation & Employment | accessdate = 31 August 2015 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160123115113/http://www.ngatitoa.iwi.nz/wp-content/uploads/PhotoGallery/2010/09/Haka-Ka-Mate-Guidelines_Final2.pdf | archivedate = 23 January 2016 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> He had hidden from them in a food-storage pit, and climbed back into the light to be met by a chief friendly to him – Te Whareangi (the "hairy man").
The haka as composed by Te Rauparaha begins with a chant:<ref name="Pomare"/><ref name=Guidelines/> {{Verse translation|lang=mi| Kikiki! Kakaka! Kauana kei waniwania taku tara kei tarawahia, kei te rua i te kerokero! He pounga rahui te uira ka rarapa ketekete kau ana To peru kairiri mau au e koro e! Hi! Ha! - Ka wehi au ka matakana, ko wai te tangata kia rere ure tirohanga ngā rua rerarera ngā rua kuri kakanui i raro! Aha ha! | Let your valor rise! Let your valor rage! We’ll ward off these haunting hands while protecting our wives and children! For thee, I defy the lightning bolts of hell while my enemies stand there in confusion! O God – to think I would tremble to a pack of wolves seeing fear, or running away, because they would surely fall in the pit of shame as food for the hounds who chow down in delight! Oh, what in the name…?}}
Then follows the main body of the haka: {{Verse translation| {{lang|mi|Ka mate, ka mate! ka ora! ka ora! Ka mate! ka mate! ka ora! ka ora! Tēnei te tangata pūhuruhuru Nāna nei i tiki mai whakawhiti te rā Ā, upane! ka upane! Ā, upane, ka upane, whiti te ra!}} | 'Tis death! 'tis death! ''(or: I may die)'' ’Tis life! ‘tis life! ''(or: I may live)'' ’Tis death! ‘tis death! ’Tis life! ‘tis life! This is the hairy man Who summons the sun and makes it shine A step upward, another step upward! A step upward, another... the Sun shines!}}
"Ka Mate" was conceived as a brief energizing haka of the [[Haka#Origins|''ngeri'']] type, where, in the absence of set movements, the performers are free to [[Extemporization (music)|extemporize]] their chanting and [[Dance improvisation|movement]] as they feel fit, without any need for synchronization.<ref name="Jackson2002">{{cite journal |last1=Jackson |first1=SJ |last2=Hokowhitu |first2=B |title=Sport, Tribes, and Technology: The New Zealand All Blacks Haka and the Politics of Identity |journal=Journal of Sport and Social Issues |date=2002 |volume=26 |issue=2 |pages=125–139 |doi=10.1177/0193723502262002 |url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/0193723502262002 |language=en |issn=0193-7235}}</ref>
==Use in rugby== {{External media | float = right | video1 = [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tdMCAV6Yd0Y "Ka Mate"], accompanied by a translation — via [[YouTube]] }} [[Image:ADAM BLAIR AND ISSAC LUKE.jpg|right|thumb|200px|[[Isaac Luke]] and [[Adam Blair]] of the [[New Zealand national rugby league team]] performing "Ka Mate"]] "Ka Mate" is the most widely known haka in New Zealand and internationally because a choreographed and synchronized version<ref name="Jackson2002"/> of the chant has traditionally been performed by the [[All Blacks]], New Zealand's international [[rugby union]] team, as well as the [[New Zealand Kiwis|Kiwis]], New Zealand's international [[rugby league]] team, immediately prior to test (international) matches. Since 2005 the All Blacks have occasionally performed another haka, "[[Kapa o Pango]]". Since the introduction of "Kapa o Pango" the longest sequence of "Ka Mate" performances by the All Blacks is nine, which occurred between 22 August 2009 and 12 June 2010.
==Ownership== {{further information|Indigenous intellectual property#Ka Mate haka}} Between 1998 and 2006, [[Ngati Toa]] attempted to trademark "Ka Mate" to prevent its use by commercial organisations without their permission.<ref> {{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/793975.stm |title=All Blacks fight to keep haka |publisher=''[[BBC News|news.bbc.co.uk]]'' |date=16 July 2000 |accessdate=3 May 2008}} </ref><ref> {{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/section/1/story.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10126807 |title= Iwi threatens to place trademark on All Black haka|publisher=''[[New Zealand Herald]]'' |date=22 May 2005 |accessdate=3 May 2008}} </ref> In 2006 the [[Intellectual Property Office of New Zealand]] declined their claim on the grounds that "Ka Mate" had achieved wide recognition in New Zealand and abroad as representing New Zealand as a whole and not a particular trader. In March 2011 The NZ Rugby Union came to an amicable agreement with the iwi not to bring the [[mana]] of the haka into disrepute.<ref> {{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/section/1/story.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10389347 |title=Iwi claim to All Black haka turned down|publisher=''[[New Zealand Herald]]'' |date=2 July 2007 |accessdate=3 May 2008}} </ref>
In 2009, as a part of a wider settlement of grievances, the [[New Zealand government]] agreed to: :"...record the authorship and significance of the haka Ka Mate to Ngāti Toa and ... work with Ngāti Toa to address their concerns with the haka... [but] does not expect that redress will result in royalties for the use of Ka Mate or provide Ngāti Toa with a veto on the performance of Ka Mate...".<ref>[http://nz01.terabyte.co.nz/ots/livearticle.asp?ArtID=1234231829 Ngāti Toa Rangatira Letter of Agreement] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100521222630/http://nz01.terabyte.co.nz/ots/LiveArticle.asp?ArtID=1234231829 |date=21 May 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/7882775.stm | work=BBC News | title=New Zealand Maori win haka fight | date=11 February 2009}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|New Zealand|Rugby league|Rugby union}} * [[Haka (sports)]] * [[Haka in popular culture]] * [[Kapa haka]] * [[List of New Zealand rugby union haka performances]] – since "Kapa o Pango" was introduced in 2005 * [[Māori music]]
==References== {{reflist}}

page.title: List of National Lacrosse Hall of Fame members

revision.comment: Disambiguate [[Agnes Irwin]] to [[Agnes Irwin School]] using [[:en:Wikipedia:Tools/Navigation_popups|popups]]
revision.text:
The '''members of the National Lacrosse Hall of Fame''' are inducted by [[US Lacrosse]] and are enshrined at the [[Lacrosse National Hall of Fame and Museum|National Lacrosse Hall of Fame]]. Members have been inducted into the [[hall of fame]] annually since 1957.<ref name="hof">{{cite web|title=Hall of Fame|url=https://www.uslacrosse.org/about-us-lacrosse/hall-of-fame|publisher=US Lacrosse|accessdate=28 November 2017}}</ref> The National Lacrosse Hall of Fame and Museum moved to US Lacrosse's new headquarters in Sparks, Maryland in 2016.
Individuals are nominated in four distinct categories: players, coaches, and contributors. Contributors can be either officials and umpires or administrators and developers. The annual number of inductees is limited to four male and four female honorees. Each year, the nominating and voting process takes place from January through April. The annual class of inductees is publicly announced over [[Memorial Day]] weekend in May, in conjunction with the [[NCAA Men's Lacrosse Championship|NCAA Men's Championships]] held the same weekend. They are then officially inducted at a ceremony in September or October.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nomination & Selection Process|url=https://www.uslacrosse.org/sites/default/files/public/documents/about-us-lacrosse/HOF-selection-process_2014.pdf|publisher=US Lacrosse|accessdate=8 December 2017}}</ref>
In 1992, [[Rosabelle Sinclair]], a pioneer of the [[women's lacrosse|women's game]], was the first woman to be inducted into the Hall of Fame.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://apps.uslacrosse.org/museum/halloffame/view_profile.php?prof_id=189 |title=Rosabelle Sinclair Hall of Fame Biography |publisher=US Lacrosse |archivedate=March 3, 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303180553/http://apps.uslacrosse.org/museum/halloffame/view_profile.php?prof_id=189}}</ref> Since Sinclair, there have been 76 other woman inductees, and, combined with 287 men, there are 364 total inductees as of the 2010 class.

{{cleanup reorganize|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox football club | clubname = Oserian F.C. | image = Oserian F.C. logo.png | fullname = Oserian Football Club | nickname = | shortname = | founded = | dissolved = | ground = [[Oserian Grounds]], [[Naivasha]] | capacity = | owntitle = | owner = | chrtitle = Chairman | chairman = | ceo = | mgrtitle = Head coach | manager = {{flagicon|KEN}} [[Sammy Omollo]] | league = [[Kenyan National Super League|National Super League]] | season = [[2013 FKF Division One|2013]] | position = 1st (Zone B, Group 2)
[[2013 FKF Division One#Promotion play-offs|Promotion play-off]] losers (promoted) }} '''Oserian Football Club''' is a [[association football|football]] club based in [[Naivasha]], Kenya.http://allafrica.com/stories/200207230177.html, The East African Standard (Nairobi) Email Print Share Kenya: Oserian's Fate Over Sponsorship Sealed They currently play in the [[Kenyan National Super League]] and are supported by the [[Oserian]] flower farm. They were promoted to the [[Kenyan Premier League]] after winning the [[FKL Nationwide League]] in [[2011 Kenyan Nationwide League|2011]], but were relegated again after finishing 15th in [[2012 Kenyan Premier League|2012]]. Under the name '''Oserian Fastac''', it won two Premier League titles,allAfrica.com: Kenya:Oserian FastacCoach Backs Fabisch http://allafrica.com/stories/200111010444.html but was forced to briefly wind up operations when its backers pulled out. This meant that the club had to start again from the bottom tier in order to return to the Premier League. Their major rivals are [[Karuturi Sports]], with whom they share the [[Naivasha derby]]. The club also has a [[Women's association football|women's football]] section which currently competes in the [[Kenyan Women's Premier League]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Kenyan National Super League plain}} {{FKF Division One}} {{Kenyan Premier League plain}} {{Kenyan Women's Premier League}} [[Category:Kenyan Premier League clubs]] [[Category:Kenyan National Super League clubs]] [[Category:FKF Division One clubs]] [[Category:Football clubs in Kenya]] {{Kenya-footyclub-stub}}

{{Motorsport venue|Name=Pittsburgh International Race Complex|Nicknames=|Image=[[Image:Pitt Race Track Map Full.jpg|200px|center|Pittsburgh International Raceway Track Map]]|Location=201 Pendale Road, [[Wampum, Pennsylvania]]|Coordinates={{coord|40|50|56.314|N|80|20|31.772|W|region:US-OH_type:landmark|display=inline,title}}|Time=[[UTC]][[UTC-5|-5]] (UTC[[UTC-4|-4]] [[Daylight saving time|DST]])|Opened=2002|Owner=|Operator=|Events='''[[Championship of Pittsburgh]]'''
''[[MotoAmerica]]''
(2017-Present)
"[[Pittsburgh Vintage Grand Prix|PVGP Historics at Pitt Race]]"
(2004-Present)|Capacity=|FIA_grade=|Layout1=North Track|Miles_first=True|Length_km=2.57|Length_mi=1.6|Turns=12|Layout2=South Track|Length_km2=1.93|Length_mi2=1.2|Turns2=8|Record_time2=|Record_driver2=|Record_team2=|Record_year2=|Record_class2=|Layout3=Full Track|Length_mi3=2.78|Length_km3=4.47|architect=Alan Wilson|former_names=BeaveRun|Turns3=19|Record_time3=1:31.03|Record_class3=Formula Atlantic}} '''Pittsburgh International Race Complex''' (commonly known as Pitt Race) is an auto racing road course located in [[Wampum, Pennsylvania]]. Pitt Race hosts amateur and professional automobile, motorcycle, and karting events. == The track == [[File:Pitt Race Ariel Photo.jpg|left|thumb|300x300px|Aerial photo of the Pitt Race facility, including the South Track addition]] Pittsburgh International Race Complex offers three track configurations. The North track configuration is 1.6 miles and the South track covers 1.2 miles. The full course is 2.78 miles in length and combines both the North and South track. All tracks feature significant elevation change throughout and were designed to follow the natural terrain. Pitt Race hosts many different sports car series such as [[Sports Car Club of America|SCCA]] and [[National Auto Sport Association|NASA]], as well as holding track days and open tests for both cars and motorcycles.{{Cite news|url=https://www.ellwoodcityledger.com/news/business/transformation-continues-at-former-beaverun/article_b2b420cb-18e0-5340-b424-a266af1e6f3c.html|title=Transformation continues at former BeaveRun|last=Ledger|first=Louise Carroll For The|work=Ellwood City Ledger|access-date=2017-06-14|language=en}} In 2017 the track will host the 8th round of the [[MotoAmerica|MotoAmerica Championship]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.motoamerica.com/pittsburgh-international-race-complex|title=Championship of Pittsburgh|work=MotoAmerica|access-date=2017-07-18|language=en}} The track also runs a program called Total Vehicle Control (TVC). It provides instruction in situational awareness, driving dynamics, skid control, emergency braking, and accident avoidance techniques. The program is targeted at commercial and emergency vehicle drivers as well as individuals.{{Cite news|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/local/west/2013/07/10/Beaver-County-s-Pitt-Race-is-like-driving-school-on-steroids/stories/201307100150|title=Beaver County's Pitt Race 'is like driving school on steroids'|work=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|access-date=2017-07-18|language=en}} [[File:Corvette C5 NASA Pitt Race.jpg|left|thumb|300x300px|C5 Corvette at NASA Event]] The 0.82 mile kart track was designed by [[Alan Wilson (motorsport)|Alan Wilson]]. It plays host to several major kart series including WKA and USPKS as well as featuring 9.5 hp rental karts.{{Cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.com/motorsports-facility-promises-to-stimulate-area-driving-enthusiasts-and-local/article_4852ce72-adf3-5932-9e1b-8eb11f8a2431.html|title=Motorsports facility promises to stimulate area driving enthusiasts and local economy|last=Editor|first=Chuck Curti, Assistant Sports|work=Timesonline.com|access-date=2017-06-20|language=en}} == History == The idea for the track came from two area attorneys, who attracted local investors to assist in the funding the facility.{{Cite news|url=http://autoweek.com/article/car-news/tracks-little-guy-designer-alan-wilson-focuses-club-level|title=Tracks For The Little Guy: Designer Alan Wilson Focuses On The Club Level|work=Autoweek|access-date=2017-06-15}} The track broke ground in December 2001. It officially opened on July 1, 2002 as BeaveRun Motorsports Complex. It included a 1.6 mile road course, a 0.82 mile [[Kart racing|kart]] track, and a six-acre [[skidpad]] used for driver training and [[autocross]]. In 2004, work began on a one-mile addition to the main track with trees being cleared and plans drawn up, but the project was put on hold in 2006.{{Cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.com/road-course-expansion-in-works-at-beaverun/article_bc1e7dd9-6cb9-527e-ae97-a7c167025df8.html|title=Road course expansion in works at BeaveRun|work=Timesonline.com|access-date=2017-08-03|language=en}} A 12,000 square-foot event center overlooking the North Track was also constructed at this time.{{Cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.com/beaverun-racetrack-ready-to-proceed-with-expansion/article_cd4f3e9a-5a45-583d-bd1b-2bc89943fb01.html|title=BeaveRun racetrack ready to proceed with expansion|work=Timesonline.com|access-date=2017-08-03|language=en}} In 2011 the track was bought by Jim and Kathy Stout, and re-branded as Pittsburgh International Race Complex. A three-stage renovation of the facility began soon after. The South Track addition, which added 1.2 miles of track, was the largest update to the facility and was completed in 2015. It can be run as its own circuit or run combined with the North Track. An expanded Vehicle Dynamics Area was also part of the facility renovations. Both the North and South Tracks were repaved in 2017. A new timing and scoring building located on pit lane was completed in 2017. == Gallery == File:Datsun 240Z Pitt Race.jpg|Datsun 240Z at Pittsburgh Vintage Grand Prix File:WKA Karting at Pitt Race.jpg|WKA Race on the Wilson Circuit File:Pitt Race Track Geometry.jpg|Detailed Geometry Track Map of Pitt Race File:AutoX Pitt Race .jpg|Steel City AutoX at Pitt Race == References == == External links == * [http://pittrace.com/ PittRace.com] - Official site of Pittsburgh International Race Complex {{MotoAmerica circuits}} {{Trans-Am tracks}} {{F3 Americas Championship circuits}} {{United States Formula 4 Championship circuits}} [[Category:Motorsport venues in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Motorsport]] [[Category:Lawrence County, Pennsylvania]]

{{For|the house of the same name in County Durham|Preston Hall, Preston-on-Tees}} {{Infobox building | name = Preston Hall, Aylesford | image = Preston Hall Aylesford front elevation.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = Front view of Preston Hall | former_names = | alternate_names = | status = | building_type = | architectural_style = Jacobean style | address = | location_town = | location_country = | current_tenants = | start_date = | completion_date = 1850 | client = | owner = | other_dimensions = | architect = [[John Thomas (sculptor)|John Thomas]] | architecture_firm = | main_contractor = }}
'''Preston Hall''' is a former manorial home and associated estate in [[Aylesford]] in the [[English county]] of [[Kent]]. It dates to the Norman period and was owned by the Culpepper family for over 400 years. Part of the estate became the [[The Royal British Legion|Royal British Legion Village]] in the 1920s and the hall itself was used as a hospital after [[World War II]]. The estate was broken up over a period of time and most of the area it once covered is now used for housing. The hall itself was transformed into 36 flats in 2015. The Heart of Kent Hospice also occupies a site on the property.
At the end of the 19th century the estate stretched from the current [[A20 road (England)|A20]] to the [[River Medway]] just south of Aylesford.<ref name=os1895> Ordnance Survey Map of Kent, XXXI.SW. Revised: 1895, Published: 1898.</ref><ref name=times13jan48>The Preston Hall Estate, near Maidstone, Kent, ''[[The Times]]'', issue 19758, 1848-01-13, p.10.</ref> The hall is located towards the southern edge of the estate, having been rebuilt there in the mid 19th century. It is around {{convert|2.5|mi|km}} north-west of [[Maidstone]] and {{convert|0.5|mi|km}} south of Aylesford. The [[M20 motorway]] and the [[Medway Valley line|Maidstone to Gillingham railway line]] both cross the former estate between the hall and the river. Junction 5 of the M20 and [[Aylesford railway station]] are on the edges of the former estate.<ref name=os1895 /><ref name=osx148>Explorer Map 148 – Maidstone & the Medway Towns, [[Ordnance Survey]], 2015-09-16.</ref>
==History== The estate dates to at least 1102. Between around 1300 and 1734 the estate was owned by the [[Culpeper baronets]]. Jeffrey Culpepper was [[High Sheriff of Kent]] twice, once between 1364–66 and again in 1374 and the family remained influential in [[Kent]] throughout their time at the hall. The Baronetcy of Culpeper of Preston Hall was created on 17 May 1627 for William Culpeper. He served as High Sheriff of Kent in 1637 and his grandson, [[Sir Thomas Culpeper, 3rd Baronet]] served as High Sheriff in 1704 and was [[Maidstone (UK Parliament constituency)|Member of Parliament for Maidstone]] between 1705 and 1713 and again between 1715 and 1723. On his death in 1723 the estates passed to Alicia Culpepper, Thomas' sister, and, though her, to her husband's family, the Milners.<ref name=burke>[[John Burke (genealogist)|Burke J]], [[Bernard Burke|Burke JB]] (1838) Culpepper of Preston Hall, ''A genealogical and heraldic history of the extinct and dormant baronetcies of England'', pp.143–144. London: John Russell Smith. ([https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=4KRAAAAAcAAJ&lpg=PA144 Available online]. Retrieved 2017-12-02).</ref><ref name=whhistory>[http://www.weston-homes.com/news/preston-hall-history--1100---1899 Preston Hall History], Weston Homes Plc, 2015-01-25. Retrieved 2017-12-03.</ref><ref name=hop>Handley S (2002) [http://www.historyofparliamentonline.org/volume/1690-1715/member/colepeper-%28culpeper%29-sir-thomas-1656-1723 COLEPEPER (CULPEPER), Sir Thomas, 3rd Bt. (c.1656-1723), of Preston Hall, nr. Maidstone, Kent], The History of Parliament. Retrieved 2017-12-05.</ref>
The Milner family lived at Preston Hall until the mid 19th century, Charles Milner also serving as High Sheriff in 1808.<ref name=gaz2feb08>{{London Gazette|issue=16115|page=173|date=1808-02-02|nolink=y}}</ref> The property was purchased by [[Edward Ladd Betts]], a successful railway contractor, in 1848.<ref name=whhistory /> When the estate was offered for sale it covered an area of {{convert|180|acre|ha}}, although much more land was in the ownership of the estate in parishes stretching from [[Boxley, Kent|Boxley]] and [[Burham]] to [[East Malling]], with farmland covering {{convert|1650|acre|ha}} and woodlands extending for {{convert|800|acre|ha}}.<ref name=times13jan48 /> Betts demolished the old house and commissioned [[John Thomas (sculptor)|John Thomas]] to build a replacement in the Jacobean style slightly to the south of the original house location.<ref name=os1895 /><ref name=nh>[https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1070492 Preston Hall], [[Historic England]]. Retrieved 2017-12-03.</ref><ref name=apc>[http://www.aylesfordparishcouncil.org.uk/Parish-History History], Aylesford Parish Council. Retrieved 2017-12-03.</ref> Thomas had worked for Betts' brother-in-law and business partner, [[Samuel Morton Peto]], at [[Somerleyton Hall]] in Suffolk.<ref name=whhistory />
Betts landscaped the estate during his time at the hall, laying out a series of carriage drivers and lawns. He built [[Aylesford railway station]] on the [[Medway Valley Line]] to make his access to Preston Hall easier.<ref name=whhistory /> Betts ran into financial difficulties after the [[Panic of 1866|banking crisis of 1866]], became insolvent the following year and was forced to sell the hall which was brought by [[Thomas Brassey]], also a railway contractor.<ref name=whhistory />
Brassey had worked with Betts and Peto in the [[Peto, Brassey and Betts]] partnership. The hall was inherited by his son, [[Henry Brassey]] who was [[Sandwich (UK Parliament constituency)|MP for Sandwich]], in 1870. On the death of Brassey's wife in 1898 the hall was inherited by their son, [[Henry Leonard Campbell Brassey]] and his wife Violet. The couple moved to [[Apethorpe Hall]] in Northamptonshire in 1904 and sold off much of the land associated with the estate which was reduced to around {{convert|24.9|acre|ha}} in area.<ref name=whhistory />
===Royal British Legion Village=== [[File:Preston Hall Colony Cottage front.jpg|thumb|Preston Hall Colony, a typical cottage, showing the outside verandah.]] [[File:Preston Hall Colony Cottage plaque.jpg|thumb|Preston Hall Colony, plaque commemorating gift of cottages by the Empress Club.]] During [[World War I]] the hall was used as a hospital and convalescent home for servicemen wounded in the war. It built a particular reputation for the treatment of [[tuberculosis]] (TB).<ref name=apc /><ref name=whhistory2>[http://www.weston-homes.com/news/preston-hall-history--1900---present-day Preston Hall History – 1900 - Present Day], Weston Homes Plc, 2015-01-28. Retrieved 2017-12-05.</ref><ref name=wtm>[http://www.visitoruk.com/Maidstone/royal-british-legion-village-C592-V14201.html Royal British Legion Village], Welcome to Maidstone. Retrieved 2017-12-05.</ref><ref name=ko26apr02>[http://www.kentonline.co.uk/maidstone/news/tributes-paid-to-devoted-chest-d-a3342/ Tributes paid to devoted chest doctor], ''[[Kent Online]]'', 2002-04-26. Retrieved 2017-12-06.</ref> After the war the site was purchased to establish a sanatorium, training colony and village for wounded servicemen and to act as a centre for the treatment of TB. The estate became known as the Preston Hall Colony.<ref name=apc /><ref name=times16mar20>Tubercular Ex-Service Men, ''[[The Times]]'', issue 42360, 1920-03-16, p.13.</ref>
At a time when the only treatment for TB was fresh air and rest, the cottages had verandas so that TB patient’s beds could be pushed outside. The cottages were large enough that patient’s families could live with them. Eventually about 30 cottages were built. Numbers of patients had fallen by 1925 when the [[Royal British Legion]] took over the running of the colony.<ref name=times15may24>Future Of Preston Hall, ''[[The Times]]'', issue 43652, 1924-05-15, p.12.</ref><ref name=times17jan31>British Legion Village, ''[[The Times]]'', issue 45723, 1931-01-17, p.8.</ref> The village quickly increased in population and became known as the British Legion Village.<ref name=rblhistory>[https://www.rbli.co.uk/page/our-history Our history], Royal British Legion Industries. Retrieved 2017-12-05.</ref> The Medical Director of the sanatorium between 1924 and 1944 was [[John McDougall (rugby union)|Dr John McDougall]] who later went on to be Chief Tuberculosis Officer of the [[World Health Organization]] from 1945.<ref>[https://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp2.pdf Former Fellows of The Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783 – 2002], [[The Royal Society of Edinburgh]], July 2006. Retrieved 2017-12-05.</ref>
The Royal British Legion maintains its presence at the village. Gavin Astor House provides specialist nursing care and there are assisted living areas for elderly forces veterans. Over 100 housing units are provided for veterans and their families and temporary accommodation is also provided on the site which provides housing for over 300 people.<ref name=rblhousing>[https://www.rbli.co.uk/page/housing-and-care Housing and care], Royal British Legion Industries. Retrieved 2017-12-05.</ref> Employment opportunities are also provided on the site and in 1972 the [[Poppy Appeal]] headquarters moved to the village.<ref name=ko9nov12>Graham M (2012) [http://www.kentonline.co.uk/kent/news/video-millions-of-poppies-start-a58861/ Video: Millions of poppies start life at Royal British Legion Village in Aylesford], ''[[Kent Online]]'', 2012-11-09. Retrieved 2017-12-05.</ref> An industrial complex in the village houses [[Britain's Bravest Manufacturing Company]], run by the Legion, including the manufacturing of road and public signs used throughout the UK.<ref name=railmag>Stephen P (2016) Made by Britain's bravest, ''Rail Magazine'', 2016-07-06, issue 804, p.60.</ref>
===Hospital=== This hall was again used as a hospital during [[World War II]] and was brought into the [[National Health Service]] when it was established in 1948.<ref name=apc /> It was used first as a specialist chest hospital before becoming a general hospital. When the Maidstone General Hospital opened in the early 1980s the hall was used as the headquarters of the Maidstone Health Authority until 2012.<ref name=wtm /><ref name=ko10nov14>McWethy C (2014) [http://www.kentonline.co.uk/malling/news/work-approved-for-crumbling-building-26742/ Experts say parts of Preston Hall, in the heart of Aylesford’s Royal British Legion Village, are at risk of crumbling and pose a risk to the public], ''[[Kent Online]]'', 2014-11-10. Retrieved 2017-12-06.</ref>
==Modern use== In March 2014 the hall was sold by the Department of Health to Weston Homes for a nominal fee to be converted into residential apartments. Some areas were in poor condition and repairs were made later in the year before a total of 36 flats were developed in the original building in 2015.<ref name=ko10nov14 /><ref name=tc>[http://www.townandcountrymag.co.uk/site/property-of-the-day-preston-hall-aylesford Property of the day: Preston Hall, Aylesford], Town & Country, 2015-11-30. Retrieved 2017-12-03.</ref><ref name=tory11feb15>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/11405894/Yours-for-195000-how-you-can-own-part-of-a-Wolf-Hall-style-Tudor-mansion.html Yours for £195,000: how you can own part of a Wolf Hall-style Tudor mansion], ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', 2015-02-11. Retrieved 2017-12-06.</ref> Other areas of the site have been developed as further areas of housing.<ref name=lawns>[https://www.redrow.co.uk/-/media/redrow-co-uk/files/developments/south-east/the-lawns-at-preston-hall-park/site-plan/160416preston-hall-site-final-4ppqxp-15416.pdf The Lawns], Preston Hall Park, Redrow Homes. Retrieved 2017-12-06.</ref><ref name=ko18jul17>McConnell E (2017) [http://www.kentonline.co.uk/malling/news/almost-4000-new-homes-planned-129045/ Hermitage Lane: 3,712 homes to be built along key route between Maidstone and Aylesford in next 20 years], ''[[Kent Online]]'', 2017-07-18. Retrieved 2017-12-06.</ref>
Part of the estate is the site of the Heart of Kent Hospice, opened in 1992.<ref name=wtm />
==Cricket ground== {{Infobox cricket ground | ground_name = Preston Hall Ground | nickname = | image = | caption = | country = England | location = [[Aylesford]], [[Kent]] | coordinates = {{Coord|51.295|N|0.477|E|type:landmark|display=title, inline}} (approx.) | establishment = 1846 <small>(first recorded match)</small> | demolished = | last used = | seating_capacity = | owner = | architect = | contractor = | operator = Preston Hall | tenants = | home club = | county club = | end1 = | end2 = | year1 = 1846–1847 | club1 = [[Kent County Cricket Club]] | year2 = 1859–1897 | club2 = Preston Hall | date = 4 December | year = 2017 | source = https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Grounds/11/289.html CricketArchive }} A [[cricket]] ground had been built within the grounds of the hall by the mid 19th century. It was used in 1846 and 1847, when the hall was owned by the Milner family, by [[Kent County Cricket Club]] for two [[first-class cricket]] matches, both played against [[Surrey County Cricket Club|Surrey]]. These were the ground's only first-class fixtures<ref name=cafc>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Grounds/11/289_f.html First-Class Matches played on Preston Hall Ground, Aylesford], CricketArchive. Retrieved 2017-12-06.</ref> and were held as part of an attempt to form a rival to the [[Canterbury]] based Kent club.<ref name=milton>Milton H (1979) Kent cricket grounds, in ''The Cricket Statistician'', no. 28, December 1979, pp.2–10.</ref>
Prior to the formation of the first county club in 1842, Kent teams had played at the [[Old County Ground]] in [[Town Malling]], {{convert|2.5|mi|km}} west of Preston Hall. The county returned to the ground to play four matches later in the 19th century. They also played over 250 matches at [[Mote Park (cricket ground)|Mote Park]] in [[Maidstone]] between 1859 and 2005.<ref name=17annual210>Grounds Records in ''Kent County Cricket Club Annual 2017'', pp.210–211. Canterbury: [[Kent County Cricket Club]].</ref> Kent's Second XI played a number of matches at Cobdown Sports Ground in [[Ditton, Kent|Ditton]], around {{convert|1|mi|km}} to the west of Preston Hall, between 1948 and 1977.<ref name=cacobdown>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Grounds/11/2048.html Cobdown Sports Ground, Aylesford], CricketArchive. Retrieved 2017-12-07.</ref>
The ground was also used for a number of non-first-class matches. Aylesford Cricket Club used the ground during the ownership of Charles Milner<ref name=milton /> and a side called Preston Hall used the ground between 1873 and 1897, as did a team bearing the name of [[Henry Brassey]]. Matches are known to have been played against a variety of well-known amateur teams including [[I Zingari]], [[Free Foresters]], The Mote, [[Royal Engineers Cricket Club|Royal Engineers]], [[Sevenoaks Vine]] and Eton Ramblers.<ref name=camisc>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Grounds/11/289_misc.html Other matches played on Preston Hall Ground, Aylesford], CricketArchive. Retrieved 2017-12-06.</ref> Areas of sports fields remain in use as playing fields on land which was once owned by the estate between the [[M20 motorway]] and the [[River Medway]],<ref name=osx148 /> but the cricket ground is no longer in existence.<ref name=17annual210 />
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == *[http://hokh.org The Heart of Kent Hospice] *[http://www.british-towns.net/sh/statelyhomes_album.asp?GetPic=202 Preston Hall] on the British Towns and Villages Network

{{For|the Welsh rugby union player|Rhodri Williams (rugby player)}} {{BLP sources|date=May 2012}} '''Rhodri Williams''' (born 10 May 1968 as '''Rhodri Ogwen Williams''') is a [[Wales|Welsh]] [[sports journalist]] from [[Barry, Vale of Glamorgan]], [[Wales]]. He is currently employed by Qatar's [[Al-Kass Sports Channel]] and anchors the network's English-speaking studio.<ref name="marhaba"/>
==TV career== Williams was a main presenter for [[Sky Sports News]] and was one of Sky Sports' main [[Rugby football|rugby]] presenters - hosting the [[Heineken Cup]] and [[Southern Hemisphere]] rugby including the [[Tri Nations (rugby union)|Tri Nations]], the [[National Provincial Championship|NPC]] in [[New Zealand]] and the [[Currie Cup]] in [[South Africa]]. He was sacked by Sky Sports in 2006 after tabloid revelations regarding his personal life. <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/rhodri-sacked-after-naked-allegations-2342171|title=Rhodri sacked after naked allegations|work=Wales Online|date=3 April 2006|accessdate=14 October 2016}}</ref>
He was the first presenter on [[L!VE TV]] ([[United Kingdom|Britain]]'s first 24-hour [[cable channel]]). In 1997 Rhodri was the quizmaster on L!VE TV's football quiz ''A Game of Two Scarves'' featuring fans and glamour models. He also hosted the station's talent show, ''[[Spanish Archer]]''.
Williams was part of the launch of [[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]] in the UK as one of the presenters on the channel's afternoon entertainment show ''5's Company'' with [[Nick Knowles]] and [[John Barrowman]]. He has presented numerous programmes for [[Welsh language]] channel [[S4C]], and also presented ''[[Animal Hospital]]''<ref>{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/smgpubs/access/73318414.html?dids=73318414:73318414&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Mar+15%2C+2001&author=&pub=Evening+Times&desc=Dinner+Date%3B+RHODRI+WILLIAMS&pqatl=google|date=March 15, 2001|work=Evening Times|page=32|accessdate=16 August 2012|location=Glasgow|quote=Rhodri Williams is filming a sixth series of BBC's Animal Hospital and is one of the presenters on the new series of Rolf's Amazing World of Animals.|title=Dinner Date; RHODRI WILLIAMS}}</ref> with [[Rolf Harris]]. In 2001, Williams appeared on [[Lily Savage's Blankety Blank]].<ref name="blanketyblank">{{cite episode|series=[[Lily Savage's Blankety Blank]]|airdate=8 April 2001|network=[[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]}}</ref>
He was the main rugby anchor for [[Setanta Sports]] and hosted various shows on [[Setanta Sports News]]. Williams presented [[ITV Wales & West|ITV Wales]]' coverage of the [[2007 Rugby World Cup]].
In 2008, Williams was contracted by [[Al Jazeera Sports]] with whom he covered the [[2008 Summer Olympics|2008 Beijing Olympics]] and the [[2011 AFC Asian Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dohaheat.libsyn.com/episode-25-rhodri-williams|title=Episode 25 - Rhodri Williams|publisher=Doha Heat Podcast|date=16 July 2014|accessdate=30 December 2014}}</ref> He also anchored 2012 [[Al-Kass Sports Channel|Al Kass]] International Cup. Later that year, he was hired full-time by Al Kass Sports Channel to host a segment known as ''QSL Review'' in an incentive to provide coverage of the [[Qatar Stars League]] to non-Arabic speakers.<ref name="marhaba">{{cite web|url=http://marhaba.com.qa/al-kass-to-cover-the-qatar-stars-league-in-english/|title=Al Kass to cover the Qatar Stars League in English|publisher=marhaba.com|date=30 September 2012|accessdate=30 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dohastadiumplusqatar.com/reaching-kids/|title=Reaching out to kids|publisher=dohastadiumplusqatar.com|date=27 February 2014|accessdate=30 December 2014}}</ref>
==Radio== Williams has been a presenter on national radio sports station [[talkSPORT]], presenting the ''Kick-off'' programme on Thursday from 19:00 to 22:00 and ''The Sunday Session.''
He has also presented radio shows for [[BBC Radio Wales]] and [[Radio Cymru]].
==Business interests== Away from the media, Williams owns three businesses in [[Cardiff]].
==Personal life== Williams is the son of famed Welsh TV (S4C) presenter/weather girl Jenny Ogwen. Rhodri was educated at Ysgol Gyfun Gymraeg Glantaf.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.rhodri.co.uk/ Rhodri Williams official site] *[http://www.imaginegolfclub.com/blog/rhodri-williams-all.htm Rhodri Williams Blog] Imagine Golf
{{DEFAULTSORT:Williams, Rhodri}} [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:British game show hosts]] [[Category:Welsh-language television presenters]] [[Category:Welsh radio presenters]] [[Category:Welsh television presenters]] [[Category:Sports journalists]] [[Category:Alumni of Cardiff University]] [[Category:People from Barry, Vale of Glamorgan]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2013}} {{Infobox stadium |stadium_name = Riccardo Silva Stadium |nickname = |image = |image_size = 250px |location = 11200 Southwest 8th Street
[[Miami|Miami, FL]] 33199 |coordinates = {{coord|25|45|9|N|80|22|40|W|region:US_type:landmark|display=it}} |broke_ground = {{Start date|1994|07|24}} |opened = {{Start date|1995|09|24}}{{cite news |title=Heralding the New Stadium|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=MH&s_site=miami&p_multi=MH&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB4D28BEA3FC1DB&p_field_direct-0=document_id|newspaper=[[The Miami Herald]]|date=September 24, 1995|accessdate=July 4, 2012|page=4}} |expanded = 2001, 2008 and 2012 |closed = |demolished = |owner = [[Florida International University]] |operator = [[Florida International University]] |surface = [[FieldTurf]] |architect = [[Rossetti Architects]]
BEA Architects |general_contractor=[[Odebrecht|Odebrecht Construction]] |suites = 19 |record_attendance=22,682 (2011 vs. [[Duke University|Duke]]) |tenants = [[FIU Panthers]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (1995–present)

[[Miami FC]] ([[North American Soccer League|NASL]]) (2016–present) |construction_cost=$3 million (Original stadium, 1994)
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|3000000|1995}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}){{cite news |title=FIU Plans $50 Million Stadium, Student Center|first=Risa|last=Polansky|url=http://www.miamitodaynews.com/news/070308/story6.shtml|newspaper=[[Miami Today]]|date=March 8, 2007|accessdate=July 4, 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110206065628/http://miamitodaynews.com/news/070308/story6.shtml|archivedate=February 6, 2011}}
US$54 million (New stadium, 2007) |former_names = FIU Community Stadium (1995–2001)
Ocean Bank Field at FIU Stadium (2001–2017) |seating_capacity=20,000 (2012) |url={{url|1=http://www.fiusports.com/Facilities/Facilities/AlfonsoFieldatFIUStadium.aspx}}}} '''Riccardo Silva Stadium''' is a [[college football]] and [[soccer]] stadium on the campus of [[Florida International University]] (FIU) in [[Miami|Miami, Florida]] and the home stadium of the [[FIU Panthers football|FIU Panthers football team]] and [[Miami FC]]. The stadium opened in 1995 and has a seating capacity of 20,000. == History == === FIU Community Stadium === FIU Community Stadium was the first dedicated sports facility at the school, replacing [[Tamiami Park|Tamiami Field]]. Construction officially began on July 24, 1994 and the facility opened on September 24, 1995, as a 7,500-seat football and track stadium. It was built as a joint venture between FIU, [[Miami-Dade County Public Schools]], [[Miami-Dade County, Florida#Parks|Miami-Dade Parks]], and the Miami-Dade County Youth Fair. In anticipation of the inaugural [[FIU Panthers football|FIU Golden Panthers football]]{{#tag:ref|FIU dropped the word "Golden" from its nickname starting in the 2010–11 school year.|group="Note"}} season in fall 2002, the university placed movable [[bleachers]] around the stadium's [[all-weather running track]] in 2001, which increased the stadium's capacity to 17,000 seats. === Renovation === {| class="wikitable" style="float:right; margin-left:1em; font-size:88%;" {{CollegePrimaryHeader|team=FIU Panthers|Years|Stadium capacity}} |- |1995–2001 |7,500 |- |2002–2007 |17,000{{cite web|url=http://www.nmnathletics.com/attachments1/1141.pdf|title=2006 FIU Football Program|publisher=FIU Athletics|format=PDF}}{{dead link|date=December 2016|bot=InternetArchiveBot|fix-attempted=yes}} |- |2008–2011 |18,000{{cite press release|title=FIU Breaks Ground On New Stadium|date=May 25, 2007|publisher=FIU Athletics|url=http://www.fiusports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=11700&ATCLID=900295|accessdate=July 4, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120704214103/http://www.fiusports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=11700&ATCLID=900295|archivedate=July 4, 2012|df=mdy}} |- |2012–present |20,000 |} In 2007, the university announced a major expansion and redesign for FIU Stadium. The redesign of FIU Stadium would increase the stadium's capacity to 45,000 fans, to be built in phases. For the first phase of the expansion, the school demolished a large portion of the original 1995 stadium. The west, south and east sides of FIU Stadium were taken down and construction began on the new, permanent stadium. The expansion was completed in September 2008 for the [[2008 FIU Golden Panthers football team|2008 football season]]. Phase one increased the stadium's capacity from 17,000 fans to 18,000, including 1,500 [[Club seating|club seats]].{{cite web|url=http://www.collegegridirons.com/sunbelt/FIUStadium.htm|title=FIU Stadium|publisher=CollegeGridirons.com|accessdate=July 4, 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629141825/http://www.collegegridirons.com/sunbelt/FIUStadium.htm|archivedate=June 29, 2011}} During construction, the [[2007 FIU Golden Panthers football team]] played its home games in the [[Miami Orange Bowl]]. The new facility opened for the first home game of the [[2008 FIU Golden Panthers football team|2008 football season]] against the [[2008 South Florida Bulls football team|South Florida Bulls]] on September 20. The Golden Panthers lost 17–9 in front of a crowd of 16,717.{{cite report|url=http://www.fiusports.com/fls/11700/Stats_Cumulative/Football/2008/fiu03.htm|title=USF vs FIU|date=September 20, 2010|publisher=FIU Athletics|accessdate=July 4, 2012|type=Stats report|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120311040708/http://www.fiusports.com/fls/11700/Stats_Cumulative/Football/2008/fiu03.htm|archivedate=March 11, 2012|df=mdy}} The team won its first game in the new stadium on October 11, 2008 against [[Sun Belt Conference]] rival the [[2008 Middle Tennessee Blue Raiders football team|Middle Tennessee State Blue Raiders]], 31–21. The team finished its first season in the new stadium with three wins and two losses. In 2009, the university began the second phase of the stadium expansion, which included the construction of a new football [[field house]]. Renovations were completed in 2012 and the capacity increased to 20,00 seats. In 2017, the university agreed to a five-year deal to rename the stadium after [[Riccardo Silva]], part owner of [[Miami FC]], which also plays at the stadium.{{Cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/sports/mls/article142503039.html|title=FIU Stadium gets facelift, new name after Miami FC owner gives record $3.76 million donation|work=miamiherald|access-date=2017-04-04|language=en}} Before the deal, Silva had donated $3.76 million for various improvements to the stadium including a new playing surface and [[Jumbotron]] video scoreboard.{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/espn/now?nowId=21-0639104629262520483-4|title=Riccardo Silva Stadium will be the new name of FIU's football stadium, sources told ESPN.|website=ESPN.com|publisher=ESPN|last1=McMurphy|first1=Brett|accessdate=30 March 2017}} === Attendance === {| class="wikitable" style="float:right; margin-left:1em; font-size:88%;" |+ Historical Attendance at FIU Stadium {{CollegePrimaryHeader|team=FIU Panthers|Rank|Attendance |Date|Game result}} |- ! 1 | 22,682 | October 1, 2011 | FIU 27, '''Duke 31'''
''(2011 Homecoming)'' |- ! 2 | 20,205 | September 12, 2011 | '''FIU 17''', UCF 10 |- ! 3 | 19,872 | September 11, 2010 | FIU 14, '''Rutgers 19''' |- ! 4 | 18,524 | September 24, 2016 | FIU 14, '''UCF 53''' |- ! 5 | 17,962 | October 24, 2015 | '''FIU 41''', Old Dominion 12
''(2015 Homecoming)'' |} On October 1, 2011 FIU Stadium drew its largest attendance in school history. A crowd of 22,268 came to watch the Panthers play the Duke Blue Devils football team for the team's 2011 homecoming game. During the game, the [[Goodyear Blimp]] made its first appearance at FIU Stadium. The [[Miami Tower]] in [[Downtown Miami]] was also lit in blue and gold from September 26 to October 1, 2011 in honor of the game.{{cite news|url=http://news.fiu.edu/2011/09/iconic-downtown-building-to-go-blue-and-gold-for-homecoming|title=Iconic Downtown Building to go Blue and Gold for Homecoming|last=Merille|first=Eduardo|date=September 1, 2011|work=FIU News|accessdate=July 4, 2012}} === Renaming === On April 3, 2017 FIU stadium was renamed Riccardo Silva Stadium.{{Cite news|url=https://therealdeal.com/miami/2017/04/03/fiu-names-stadium-for-entrepreneur-real-estate-investor-riccardo-silva/|title=FIU names stadium for entrepreneur, real estate investor Riccardo Silva|date=2017-04-03|work=The Real Deal Miami|access-date=2017-04-04|language=en-US}} The decision to rename the stadium is in recognition of the support given by Italian businessman [[Riccardo Silva]] to the FIU Department of Intercollegiate Athletics since 2015. The newly renamed stadium home opener featured a performance by Grammy nominated Latin star [[Maluma (singer)|Maluma]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcmiami.com/news/local/Colombian-Music-Sensation-Maluma-Set-to-Perform-at-Miami-FCs-Historic-Home-Opener-375110211.html|title=Maluma Set to Perform at Miami FC's Home Opener|work=NBC 6 South Florida|access-date=2018-04-23|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.miamifc.com/news/2016/04/01/global-music-idol-maluma-joins-miami-fc-at-historic-home-opener|title=Global music idol Maluma joins Miami FC at historic home opener|access-date=2018-04-23}} Maluma returned to the stadium in April 2018 to record the video for the Spanish language version of [[Jason Derulo]]'s World Cup 2018 anthem for Coca-Coca.{{Cite news|url=http://www.miamifc.com/news/2018/04/17/maluma-returns-to-riccardo-silva-stadium-to-shoot-new-music-video|title=Maluma Returns to Riccardo Silva Stadium to Shoot New Video for Coca Cola's 2018 FIFA World Cup Anthem|access-date=2018-04-23}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.sun-sentinel.com/features/fl-reg-music-videos-filmed-in-miami-20180423-story.html|title=Drake, Taylor Swift, Zayn and others make Miami music videos a trend again|last=Diaz|first=Johnny|work=Sun-Sentinel.com|access-date=2018-04-25|language=en-US}} == Structure and facilities == Designed by [[Rossetti Architects]],{{cite web|url=http://facilities.fiu.edu/projects/BT-842/BT-842FIUStadiumExpansionMasterPlanAELegalAd.pdf|title=NOTICE TO ARCHITECT/ENGINEERS – BT-842 FIU Stadium Expansion & Master Plan|date=September 9, 2011|publisher=[[Florida International University]]|page=1–3|format=PDF|accessdate=July 4, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130124214750/http://facilities.fiu.edu/projects/BT-842/BT-842FIUStadiumExpansionMasterPlanAELegalAd.pdf|archivedate=January 24, 2013|df=mdy}} the stadium has a {{convert|6500|sqft|m2|adj=on}} Panther Club on the ground level, an upper concourse for additional fan seating and concessions, a [[jumbotron]] scoreboard, and 19 [[luxury suites]]. Seating includes chairback seats and bench seating, all with backrests. Panther fans shout "Rattle the Cage!" and fans will stomp and jump in unison on the bleachers creating a very loud [[reverberation]] throughout the steel and aluminum stadium.{{citation needed|date=July 2012|reason=Every fan says this about every stadium.}} The Rattling of the Cage is done throughout the game, notably while the team is on defense and during cheers.{{cite web|url=http://www.antisteez.com/news/fiu-rattles-the-city/|title=FIU Rattles The City|date=November 30, 2010|publisher=Antisteez.com|accessdate=July 4, 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.constructionequipmentguide.com/Odebrecht-Building-Expandable-Stadium-at-FIU/9054/|title=Odebrecht Building Expandable Stadium at FIU|last=Brooks|first=Jeff|date=August 1, 2007|publisher=ConstructionEquipmentGuide.com|id=9054|edition=Southeast}} In April 2017 Riccardo Silva Stadium has also seen significant improvements made to the facility over the last two months, with completion of two major projects. The first is the installation of a new state of the art playing surface. The new surface, FieldTurf’s Revolution 360, features fibers that provide for optimal durability, resilience and feel and is used by many of the country’s biggest NFL and soccer teams. Riccardo Silva Stadium has also been enhanced by installation of a new videoboard, replacing the existing scoreboard, providing a huge boost to the fan experience at The Miami FC’s soccer games. Measuring approximately 31x59 feet, the new videoboard will feature a 13HD pixel layout, the premier technology for outdoor applications within the sports industry. It will have full live video and instant replay capabilities, along with multiple zones of content, including statistics and graphics. In April 2011, the field was named Alfonso Field after alumnus [[David F. Alfonso]]. The facility also includes a two-story, {{convert|50000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} field house, named for [[Higher education governing board#Trustees|trustee]] R. Kirk Landon, which includes a {{convert|14000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} weight room. The stadium also includes {{convert|8500|sqft|m2}} of locker rooms, an equipment room, a full-service athletic training facility, a ticket office, a merchandise area, and an FIU Athletics Hall of Fame. [[File:FIU Stadium, October 13, 2012.jpg|thumb|center|900x700px|A wide photograph of the stadium]] == Transportation == [[Miami-Dade Transit]] serves Riccardo Silva Stadium with [[Miami-Dade Transit#Metrobus|Metrobus]] lines 8, 11, 24, and 71. Bus lines 8, 11 and the 24 connect Riccardo Silva Stadium directly with [[Downtown Miami]] and [[Brickell]].{{cite web|url=http://www.miamidade.gov/transit/metrobus.asp|title=Metrobus|publisher=Miami-Dade County|accessdate=July 4, 2012}} For students at the [[Biscayne Bay Campus]], the Riccardo Silva Golden Panther Express offers direct bus service to Riccardo Silva Stadium. Riccardo Silva Stadium has multiple [[Bicycle stand|bike racks]] for fans traveling by bicycle. Parking on game days is free. [[Tailgate party|Tailgate]] parking areas around the stadium open six hours before kickoff.{{cite web|url=http://www.fiusports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=11700&ATCLID=1554948|title=Game Day Parking|publisher=FIU Athletics|accessdate=July 4, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120610140421/http://www.fiusports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=11700&ATCLID=1554948|archivedate=June 10, 2012|df=mdy}} == See also == * [[Shula Bowl]] * [[FIU Baseball Stadium]] * [[FIU Arena]] * [[List of NCAA Division I FBS football stadiums]] == Notes == {{Reflist|group="Note"}} == References == {{Reflist|2}} == External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110711005319/http://www.fiusports.com/SportSelect.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=11700&KEY=&SPID=10392&SPSID=87363 FIU Stadium Construction – Official Website] * [http://facilities.fiu.edu/ FIU Facilities Planning & Construction Site] * [http://metroatlantic.wordpress.com/2012/09/09/fiu-stadium-construction-history/ FIU Stadium construction history] {{Miami FC}} {{FIU Panthers football navbox}} {{Florida International University}} {{Conference USA football venue navbox}} {{Florida college football venues}} {{Fort Lauderdale Strikers}} {{NASL Stadiums}} {{2011 CONCACAF Gold Cup venues}} {{LFL Venues}} {{Greater Miami}} [[Category:College football venues]] [[Category:FIU Panthers football]] [[Category:Fort Lauderdale Strikers stadiums]] [[Category:CONCACAF Gold Cup stadiums]] [[Category:Legends Football League venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Miami]] [[Category:American football venues in Florida]] [[Category:1995 establishments in Florida]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1995]] [[Category:North American Soccer League stadiums]] [[Category:Miami FC]]

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=January 2013}} [[File:Skydiving in Central London!! cropped.jpg|right|thumb|Skysurfer on a simulator]]
'''Sky surfing''' is a type of [[skydiving]] in which the skydiver wears a board attached to his or her feet and performs [[surfing]]-style [[aerobatics]] during [[freefall]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.topendsports.com/sport/more/skysurfing.htm|title=Skysurfing the Sport|website=www.topendsports.com|language=en|access-date=2017-08-19}}</ref>
The boards used are generally smaller than actual [[surfboard]]s, and look more like [[snowboard]]s or large [[skateboard]]s. The attachment to the feet is normally made removable, so that if the skydiver loses control or has difficulty opening their parachute, the board can be jettisoned. Surf Flite was the first sky board company, copyrighted by [[Jerry Loftis]] (January 1, 1969 – August 12, 1998).
Skysurfing is a skill requiring considerable practice. The simplest skysurfing technique is to stand upright on the board during freefall, and tilt the nose of the board down to generate forward movement. However even this basic technique is a balancing act which experienced skydivers find tricky to learn. The extra drag of the board tends to upset the balance and make the skydiver flip over. The jumper must also learn to control the board and their body position so as to open the parachute in a stable configuration. More advanced aerobatics such as loops, rolls and helicopter spins, are more difficult still and are tackled once the basics have been mastered. Since some techniques require constant spinning at a high speed, one technique some skysurfers take to is tightly wrapping ace bandages all the way up the arms and legs to keep the blood from pooling at the end of your limbs. Even with the bandage technique, however, many techniques in skysurfing can be extremely painful.
Because of the possibility of dropping the board, not every skydiving club permits skysurfing, and only a minority of skydivers have attempted this recent specialisation in the sport.
When a skysurfer is filmed by another skydiver falling alongside them, the resulting film gives the appearance that the skysurfer is riding on the air in the same way a surfer rides on a wave. The downward motion is not very apparent and this creates the illusion that a skysurfer is gliding on air currents like a sailplane or hang glider. In fact a skysurfer always falls at a high speed comparable to any other freefalling parachutist. The competitive discipline of skysurfing is a team sport consisting of a skysurfer and a camera flyer with a video camera.
== History == The Sky Surf was invented by two French skydivers, Dominique Jacquet and Jean-Pascal Oron in 1986 but it became popular and gained recognition during the 1990s thanks to the efforts of the first few exponents to master the more complex aerobatics, such as the late [[Patrick de Gayardon]] and the late Jerry Loftis. The rise of skysurfing coincided with other new-age disciplines in skydiving, such as [[Freestyle skydiving|freestyle]] and [[freeflying]]. Freestyle skydiving is a balletic, mostly individual style which seeks to extend the sport beyond the traditional belly-to-earth flat position used by most skydivers who make formations with their bodies.
Freeflying is also a form of skydiving using a variety of body positions, such as head-down or feet-to-earth, while still building formations with others. These evolutions in skydiving have taken the sport further away from the traditional image of a daredevil stunt.
In 1991, after performing standing on a surfboard for a skysurfing advertisement of [[Coca-Cola|Coca Cola]] Ray Palmer became the first Australian skysurfer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dropzone.com/forum/Skydiving_C1/General_Skydiving_Discussions_F18/Skysurfing_P2234113|title=Skysurfing : Dropzone.com Skydiving Forums|website=www.dropzone.com|access-date=2017-08-19}}</ref> Skysurfing reached its peak in popularity in the late 1990s. Skysurfers were featured in prime time television commercials for major brands like [[Pepsi]] and [[AT&T]]. Competitive team skysurfing was featured as part of the [[ESPN]] [[X Games]] from 1995 to 2000. In 1996 and 1997, the [[SSI Pro Tour]] staged eight X-Trials qualifying events in both North America and Europe. During this six-year period, pro skysurf teams received a total of $392,000 in cash winnings and the discipline garnered over 100 hours of global TV exposure without incident. After ESPN decided not to renew the sport for the seventh season, skysurfing has become exceptionally rare in the skydiving community. Reasons for the decline include the rise in popularity of freeflying and [[wingsuit flying]], the hazards associated with flying and releasing the board, and the dwindling number of experienced skysurfers to train new pilots.
== Competitions == In general, a sky surfing team include two persons: a sky surfer and a camera flier. Judges give scores to a sky surfing team not only for the variety of tricks and the total performance but also for the skills of camera flier to catch the best moments of performance.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u3NGyquUc7EC&pg=PA30&lpg=PA30|last=|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> 75% of the total score is calculated on sky surfer's performance, and the rest is made up on the cameraman's score.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UpF_CT5NTQwC&pg=PT42&lpg=PT42|last=|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref>
The first Skysurf World Championship was held in Efes, [[Turkey]] on 13–21 September 1997 by the International Parachuting Committee.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i7eRl7Az4KEC&pg=PA112&lpg=PA112|last=|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref>
Main sky surfing competitions are USA national sky surf Championships, Sky surfing world Championships, ESPN X games, European Sky surfing Championships and SSI pro tour sky surfing.
==Notable skysurfers== *[[Patrick de Gayardon]] *[[Troy Hartman]] *[[Valery Rozov]] *[[Sammy Vassilev - a.k.a Popov]] *[[Robin Berg]] *[[Damien Hrdlika]] *[[Scott Smith (skysurfer)|Scott Smith]] *[[Tanya Garcia (skysurfer)|Tanya Garcia]] *[[Mary Tortomasi]] *[[Rob Harris (skysurfer)|Rob Harris]] *[[Eric Fradet]] *[[Oliver Furrer]] *[[Sean MacCormac]] *[[Clif Burch]]

{{Infobox organization | name = Swiss Dynamic Shooting Federation | native_name = Schweizer Verband für Dynamisches Schiessen (''[[German language|German]]''), Fédération Suisse de Tir Dynamique (''[[French language|French]]''), Ferdazione Svizzera di Tiro Dinamico (''[[Italian language|Italian]])''. | native_name_lang = [[German language|German]], [[French language|French]], [[Italian language|Italian]] | named_after = | image = File:Logo of the Swiss Dynamic Shooting Federation.png | image_size = | alt = | caption = | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | map2 = | map2_size = | map2_alt = | map2_caption = | abbreviation = | motto = | predecessor = | merged = | successor = | formation = {{start date|1976|11|20|df=y}} | founder = | founding_location = | extinction = | merger = | type = | tax_id = <!-- or | vat_id = (for European organizations) --> | registration_id = <!-- for non-profit org --> | status = | purpose = | headquarters = | location = | coords = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|display=inline,title}} --> | region = | services = | products = | methods = | fields = | membership = | membership_year = | language = | owner = <!-- or | owners = --> | sec_gen = | leader_title = [[President]] | leader_name = | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | board_of_directors = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = [[International Practical Shooting Confederation]] | subsidiaries = | secessions = | affiliations = | budget = | budget_year = | revenue = | revenue_year = | disbursements = | expenses = | expenses_year = | endowment = | staff = | staff_year = | volunteers = | volunteers_year = | slogan = | mission = | website = {{URL|ipsc.ch}} | remarks = | formerly = | footnotes = }} '''Swiss Dynamic Shooting Federation (SVDS)''' is the [[Switzerland|Swiss]] association for [[practical shooting]] under the [[International Practical Shooting Confederation]]. [[Switzerland]] hosted the first [[1975 IPSC Handgun World Shoot|IPSC Handgun World Shoot in 1975]].<ref>[http://www.ipsc.ch/Geschichte.htm Schweizer Verband für Dynamisches Schiessen | SVDS - Geschichte]</ref>

revision.comment: /* Terms used */
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{other uses}}
'''The Beautiful Game''' ({{lang-pt|o jogo bonito}}) is a nickname for [[association football]] popularised by the Brazilian professional footballer [[Pelé]]. Although the exact origin of the phrase is disputed, football commentator [[Stuart Hall (presenter)|Stuart Hall]] used it in 1958. Hall admired [[Peter Doherty (footballer)|Peter Doherty]] when he went to see [[Manchester City]] play at [[Maine Road]] and used the term "The Beautiful Game" to describe Doherty's style when playing.<ref>{{cite news |title=Stuart Hall |last=Harper |first=Nick |quote=The player I fell in love with and who inspired me to coin the phrase "the beautiful game" was Peter Doherty, an inside forward, my first hero. |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2003/may/02/newsstory.sport11 |work=The Guardian |location=London |date=2 May 2003 |accessdate=24 April 2011}}</ref>
==Etymology== The exact origins of the term are disputed. The origin has been attributed to Brazilian footballer [[Didi (footballer)|Waldyr Pereira (Didi)]],<ref name="Moore">{{cite news |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/world-cup-2010/7890542/Brian-Moore-South-Africa-World-Cup-besmirched-beautiful-game.html |author= Moore, Brian |title= South Africa World Cup besmirched 'beautiful' game |date= 15 July 2010 |newspaper= The Daily Telegraph |location=London |accessdate= 18 May 2012}}</ref> and the presenter [[Stuart Hall (presenter)|Stuart Hall]] claimed to have originated it in 1958.<ref name="Moore"/><ref>Hall, S; Mayo, S: ''The Daily Mayo'', 6 May 2009, BBC Radio 5 Live</ref> The English author and football fanatic [[H. E. Bates]] used the term earlier, including in a 1952 newspaper piece extolling the virtues of the game entitled "Brains in the Feet".<ref>{{cite news | title=The Sunday Times | last=Bates | first=H. E. | date=16 November 1952 | page=4 | url=http://www.hebatescompanion.com/node/1091 }}</ref>
Earlier writers used the term in 1848 to describe the game of ''[[baaga'adowe]]'', a forerunner of [[lacrosse]] as played by [[Ojibwe]] at [[Vauxhall Gardens]] in [[London]],<ref>{{cite book | title=Notes of eight year's travels and residence in Europe... | last=Catlin | first=George | date=1848 | page=119 | url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=q94cDaXGuhUC&pg=PA119&dq=%22the+beautiful+game%22+ball&hl=en&sa=X&ei=8bboTuxqpa-JAuXInJQC&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22the%20beautiful%20game%22%20&f=false}}</ref> and to [[tennis]] in 1890.<ref>{{cite book | title=Tennis | last=Heathcote | first=John Moyer | date=1890 | page=10 |author2=Edward Oliver Pleydell-Bouverie |author3=Arthur Campbell Ainger | url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=khYLAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA10&dq=%22the+beautiful+game%22+ball&hl=en&sa=X&ei=5rXoTvOVDsrjiAKo0rz7AQ&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22the%20beautiful%20game%22&f=false}}</ref>
==Usage== [[File:Pelé Mar del Plata 1965.PNG|thumb|upright|[[Pelé]]]] Brazilian footballer [[Pelé]] is credited with making the phrase synonymous with football.<ref name=”Fox”/><ref>{{cite news|title=The World Cup will show why football is still a beautiful game|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/10887009/The-World-Cup-will-show-why-football-is-still-a-beautiful-game.html|issue=12 June 2014|publisher=The Telegraph}}</ref> In 1977, he named his autobiography ''My Life and the Beautiful Game''. The book's dedication reads "I dedicate this book to all the people who have made this great game the Beautiful Game."<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7PdWkxoZ0l0C&q=I+dedicate+this+book#v=onepage&q=dedicate&f=false |authors= Pelé, Robert L. Fish, Shep Messing |title= My Life and the Beautiful Game: The Autobiography of Pelé |year= 2007 |isbn= 9781602391963 |page= v}}</ref> The phrase has entered the language as a description for football.<ref name=”Fox”>[http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2016/05/12/pele-journey-from-street-urchin-to-soccer-greatest-star-hits-big-screen.html "Pelé's journey from street urchin to soccer's greatest star hits the big screen"]. Fox News. Retrieved 31 May 2017</ref>
It is used as a title for the 13-part 2002 series charting the history of the game: ''History of Football: The Beautiful Game'', narrated by the actor [[Terence Stamp]].<ref>Brown, David (2004). "God and Enchantment of Place: Reclaiming Human Experience". p. 398. Oxford University Press</ref>
The song “[[Wavin' Flag]]” – rapper [[K'naan]]‘s [[Coca-Cola]] promotional anthem for the 2010 World Cup in South Africa – contained the lyric “let’s rejoice in the Beautiful Game.”<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/10342791 ““Rapper K'Naan's Wavin' Flag in World Cup triumph”]. BBC. Retrieved 17 October 2018</ref>
In January 2014, [[New Model Army (band)|New Model Army]] released a song called The Beautiful Game in support of the project "Spirit of Football".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theball.tv/2014/2014/01/09/new-model-armys-beautiful-game/ |title=New Model Army’s "Beautiful Game" « The Ball 2014 |publisher=Theball.tv |accessdate=28 May 2014}}</ref> A football [[podcast]] was released with the title "The Beautiful Game".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.SoccerTheBeautifulGame.com |title=The Beautiful Game |publisher=Soccerthebeautifulgame.com |accessdate=28 May 2014}}</ref>
==Terms used== Sportswear company [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] has referenced the beautiful game in its football commercials. In 1996, a Nike commercial titled "Good vs Evil" was a gladiatorial game set in a [[Roman amphitheatre]] where ten football players from around the world, including [[Eric Cantona]], [[Ronaldo (Brazilian footballer)|Ronaldo]], [[Paolo Maldini]], [[Luís Figo]], [[Patrick Kluivert]] and [[Jorge Campos]], defend "the beautiful game" against a team of demonic warriors, which culminates in Cantona receiving the ball from Ronaldo, pulling up his shirt collar, and delivering the final line, "Au Revoir", before striking the ball and destroying evil.<ref name="Jackson">{{cite book|last1=Jackson|first1=Steven J.|title=Sport, Culture and Advertising: Identities, Commodities and the Politics of Representation|date=10 November 2004|publisher=Routledge|page=186}}</ref>
[[File:Adidas Beau Jeu.jpg|thumb|left|[[Adidas Beau Jeu]], French for "Beautiful Game"]] Nike also uses the [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] phrase ''Joga bonito''—meaning "play beautifully", and not "beautiful game", which would be ''Jogo bonito''—as one of its slogans for football products.<ref>Antony Young (2007). "Profitable Marketing Communications: A Guide to Marketing Return on Investment". p. 138. Kogan Page Publishers,</ref><ref>Steve Hatch, Jim Taylor (2009). "Rigorous Magic: Communication Ideas and their Application". John Wiley & Sons,</ref> Nike began using the slogan ''Joga bonito'' in a campaign preceding the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]] in an attempt to curb players' behaviours on the pitch. In collaboration with, and promoted by, former international footballer Eric Cantona (who once karate-kicked a fan), Nike released a series of adverts to promote a game that is skillful and dignified, not riddled with theatrics and poor sportsmanship.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2006/jul/18/letfootballeatitself |title=Let football eat itself |last=Kane |first=Pat |date=18 July 2006 |accessdate=22 September 2014 |work=The Guardian}}</ref>
Sportswear company [[Adidas]] named an official [[Ball (association football)|match ball]] of [[UEFA Euro 2016]] ''[[Adidas Beau Jeu]]'' which translates to "The Beautiful Game" in English.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/international/euro-2016-adidas-unveil-beau-jeu-the-tournaments-official-match-ball-a6731786.html "Euro 2016: Adidas unveil 'Beau Jeu', the tournament's official match ball"]. ''The Independent''. Retrieved 30 May 2017</ref>
== Further reading == * Gregg Bocketti, ''[[The Invention of the Beautiful Game|The Invention of the Beautiful Game: Football and the Making of Modern Brazil]]'' (Gainesville: UP of Florida, 2016)
==See also== {{portal|Association football}} *[[Glossary of association football terms]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Association football terminology]] [[Category:Football in Brazil]] [[Category:Pelé]]

revision.text:
{{about|the baseball statistic|the Matt Christopher novel|Wild Pitch (novel)|the American hip hop record label|Wild Pitch Records}}
In [[baseball]], a '''wild pitch''' (abbreviated '''WP''') is charged against a [[pitcher]] when his [[pitch (baseball)|pitch]] is too high, too short, or too wide of [[home plate]] for the [[catcher]] to control with ordinary effort, thereby allowing a baserunner, perhaps even the batter-runner on an [[uncaught third strike]], to advance.
A wild pitch usually passes the catcher behind home plate, often allowing runners on base an easy chance to advance while the catcher chases the ball down. Sometimes the catcher may block a pitch, and the ball may be nearby, but the catcher has trouble finding the ball, allowing runners to advance.
A closely related statistic is the [[passed ball]]. As with many [[baseball statistics]], whether a pitch that gets away from a catcher is counted as a wild pitch or a passed ball is at the discretion of the [[official scorer]]. The benefit of the doubt is usually given to the catcher if there is uncertainty; therefore, most of these situations are scored as wild pitches. If the pitch was so low as to touch the ground, or so high that the catcher has to jump to get to it, or so wide that the catcher has to lunge for it, it is usually then considered a wild pitch and not a passed ball. Because the pitcher and catcher handle the ball much more than other fielders, certain misplays on pitched balls are defined in Rule 10.13 as wild pitches and passed balls. No [[error (baseball)|error]] shall be charged when a wild pitch or passed ball is scored.
[[File:Cannon Ball Stemmeyer.jpg|right|thumb|150px|[[Bill Stemmyer]] threw an MLB-record 63 wild pitches in one season.]] A wild pitch may only be scored if one or more runners advance. If the bases are empty, or the catcher retrieves the ball quickly and the runner(s) are unable to advance, a wild pitch is not charged. A scored run due to a wild pitch is recorded as an [[earned run]]. A runner who advances on a wild pitch is not credited with a [[stolen base]] unless he breaks before the pitcher begins his delivery.
==Records== [[Nolan Ryan]] is the modern-era leader in the category, throwing 277 wild pitches over his 27 years in [[Major League Baseball]]. He also led his [[sports league|league]] in the category in six different seasons. However, the all-time record belongs to [[Tony Mullane]], who threw 343 in the early years of the game from 1881 to 1894. After Ryan's 277, the next pitcher on the list is [[Mickey Welch]] 274, followed by [[Tim Keefe]]'s 233.
[[Bill Stemmyer]] still holds the single-season record, throwing 63 wild pitches in 1886. Since 1900, however, the highest total in a season has been 30 (by [[Red Ames]] in 1905). The modern record in a single game is 6, held by three different pitchers.
[[R.A. Dickey]], [[Phil Niekro]], [[Walter Johnson]], and [[Kevin Gregg]] all hold the modern-era regular season single inning wild pitch record with four. [[Rick Ankiel]], however, threw five wild pitches in the 3rd inning of the first game of the [[2000 NLDS]]. [[Bert Cunningham]] of the [[Players' League]] (considered a major league) in 1890 also threw five in an inning. [[Adam Ottavino]] on June 26, 2017 set the MLB record of five runs scored on four wild pitches.
The current active leader (prior to the 2017 season) is [[Félix Hernández]], with 132 wild pitches. The only other active pitchers with 100+ wild pitches are [[John Lackey]] with 114 and [[Tim Lincecum]] with 107.
==Sources== *[https://www.baseball-reference.com/leaders/WP_career.shtml Baseball Reference – MLB Career Leaders and Records for Wild Pitches]
==External links== *[http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/downloads/y2007/10_the_official_scorer.pdf Baseball Rules] See section 10.13
